Introduction

Pinworm infection, or enterobiasis, is a common, highly transmissible intestinal helminth infection that primarily affects school-aged children.  Transmission is via ingestion of eggs, and the hallmark symptom is nocturnal perianal itching.  Diagnosis is via visualization of worms or eggs.

Pathogenesis



Enterobiasis, caused by the pinworm Enterobius vermicularis, is a common helminth infection in school-aged children.



Transmission occurs via ingestion of eggs, typically from unwashed hands after the handling of contaminated food or objects (eg, bedding, clothing) (

figure 1
).  The larvae develop into adult worms within the distal small intestine and colon.  At night, female worms migrate through the rectum and deposit eggs in the perianal region; eggs and worms in the perianal area cause an inflammatory reaction, resulting in perianal itching (pruritus ani).  Mature pinworms can also spread to the vagina and cause vulvovaginitis.  Scratching contaminates the hands, and eggs can be ingested by the same individual or spread to others.

Risk factors



  • Age 5-10.
  • Close contact (eg, household member) or crowded conditions (eg, day care, school).
  • Poor hygiene.

Clinical presentation



Although pinworm infection is often asymptomatic, the most common presenting symptom is perianal pruritus, particularly at night.  Patients may have poor sleep due to itching, and a high worm burden may also cause abdominal pain and/or nausea.  Examination classically shows perianal erythema and excoriations; mobile worms at the anal verge may be visualized in some cases.



Less commonly, worm migration to the vulvar and vaginal areas may cause symptoms of vulvovaginitis, including itching, erythema, and nonspecific mucoid discharge.  Concomitant perianal findings are typically present on examination in these cases.

Differential diagnosis



  • Perianal streptococcal skin infection:  Perianal itching and pain in school-aged children is characteristic; symptoms are generally present throughout the day and would not be present primarily at night.  Classic examination findings include a bright red, sharply demarcated perianal rash with a positive streptococcal rapid test or culture.
  • Candida infection:  Candidiasis can involve the perianal area and cause pruritus ani, as well as vulvovaginitis in girls with vaginal pruritus, erythema, and discharge, usually in the setting of recent antibiotic use.  Skin findings may include a beefy-red rash within skinfolds (eg, intertrigo) and associated satellite lesions; vaginal involvement results in a thick, white vaginal discharge.
  • Scabies (
    figure 2
    ):  This highly contagious mite infestation presents with intensely pruritic papules usually involving the interdigital web spaces, axillae, wrists, and genitalia.  Localized perianal symptoms are not typical.
  • Hemorrhoids (
    figure 3
    ):  External hemorrhoids are most common in children and may cause perianal itching with pain.  On examination, external hemorrhoids present as bluish, soft nodules, often associated with anal skin tags.
  • Sexually transmitted infection:  Anal warts and gonorrhea can cause anal itching.  Small, flesh-colored verrucous lesions are consistent with warts, whereas gonorrhea typically causes pain with defecation and stool that may be coated with purulent discharge; trauma (eg, lacerations, bruising) may be evident.  Evaluation for sexual abuse is warranted in children with these findings.

Diagnosis



A definitive diagnosis of pinworm infection is based on visualization of adult worms or eggs.  Visual inspection of the perianal region and undergarments may reveal mobile worms (approximately 0.5 in long, white, thread-like), whereas eggs can be visualized using either the "tape test" or "paddle test."  These tests use an adhesive surface applied to the perianal region, ideally in the morning; Enterobius eggs, which are small and oval, adhere to the tape and are visualized under microscopy (

image 1
).  Because the sensitivity of an individual test is low, 3 separate examinations are recommended.  Stool cultures are of limited value because eggs are rarely passed in the stool.



In the setting of classic symptoms and examination findings, a presumptive diagnosis can be considered without visualization of worms or eggs.

Management and prognosis



First-line treatment options for pinworm infection include albendazole, mebendazole, or pyrantel pamoate.  The patient and all household contacts (even if asymptomatic) should be treated because the infection is highly transmissible, and the dose should be repeated in 2 weeks to ensure eradication of residual eggs hatched after the first treatment.  Hygienic measures include frequent handwashing, fingernail trimming, and laundering of bedding and clothing.



There are typically no long-term sequelae, but reinfection is common.

Summary
